title: 112_s922
content: The Urban Jobs Act of 2011 may be cited as the ``Urban Jobs Act of 2011''. Congress finds that one-third of minority youth are unemployed, the labor force participation rate is lower for individuals without a high school diploma, African-American and Hispanic students have a lower graduation rate, high school dropouts cost the nation billions in lost wages, and only 52 percent of students in large cities graduate from high school. High school dropouts earn significantly less over their lifetime compared to graduates. Approximately 75 percent of State prison inmates and 59 percent of Federal prison inmates have not completed high school. Increasing the high school completion rate by 1 percent for all men ages 20 to 60 would save the United States $1.4 billion annually in reduced costs associated with crime. A 10-percent increase in the male high school graduation rate would reduce arrest rates for murder and assault by about 20 percent, motor vehicle theft by 13 percent, and arson by 8 percent. The purpose of this Act is to provide resources to prevent disproportionate incarceration of eligible youth, especially minority youth, and prepare them for employment or education leading to economic self-sufficiency and advancement. The Act aims to prevent disproportionate incarceration of eligible youth, especially minority youth, and prepare them for employment or education leading to economic self-sufficiency and advancement through job training, education, and support services. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 includes a new section on Urban Jobs Programs (SEC. 173B) aimed at providing job training, education, and support services to eligible youth, particularly minority youth, to prevent disproportionate incarceration and promote economic self-sufficiency. The Urban Jobs Programs under the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 aims to provide resources for establishing a feeder system for youth aged 18-24 in urban communities, offering employment or education leading to employment through national intermediaries. It also focuses on preparing eligible youth for employment through a comprehensive set of services and aims to prevent disproportionate incarceration of minority youth in urban areas. The term 'eligible youth' refers to individuals aged 18-24 who are not in school or have been involved in the criminal justice system. A 'national intermediary' is a nonprofit organization with a network in urban communities, expertise in working with youth, and a long history of operation. 'Recidivism' is defined as a tendency to reoffend, and an 'unsubsidized job' is employment without financial assistance. The Urban Jobs Program provides grants to national intermediaries for comprehensive services to eligible youth in urban communities, offering pathways to employment or education leading to employment. To qualify for a grant, a national intermediary must submit an application as specified by the Secretary. The Secretary may require a grant application to include a request for funding, proposed uses of funds, and goals for the Urban Jobs Program participants, such as increased employment, reduced recidivism, improved education attainment, and industry certifications. The curr_chunk describes the necessary components of a program for urban youth, including industry-recognized certificates, community partnerships, staff expertise in youth development, and creating caring relationships and goals for program participants. The curr_chunk outlines key components for a program for urban youth, including attainment of employment or higher education, community service participation, workplace skill development, fostering a sense of responsibility for the future. The curr_chunk describes the responsibilities and goals of the Urban Jobs Program, including developing plans, reducing risk-taking behaviors, improving educational and employment outcomes, reducing recidivism, and attaining industry-recognized certificates. The Urban Jobs Program grant includes case management, educational services, and employment/job readiness activities to help participants navigate the program and connect to career pathways. The Urban Jobs Program grant offers various support services such as mentoring, internships, training, personal development, and job placement. It also provides health, nutrition, substance abuse counseling, housing assistance, and other necessary support services. Additionally, a limitation of 2 percent of funds is set for expenses related to this program. The Secretary of Labor is required to submit a progress report to relevant committees annually. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, established by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members from the private sector and high-growth industries. The program under this section is not subject to evaluations required under section 172. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, established by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members from high-growth industries. Members are appointed for the life of the Committee and analyze program design, strategic priorities, and guidelines. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, established by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members from high-growth industries. Members are appointed for the life of the Committee and analyze program design, strategic priorities, and guidelines. The Committee shall prepare and submit periodic reports to the Secretary with recommendations. Members do not receive compensation but are allowed travel expenses. Federal Government employees may be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, established by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members from high-growth industries. Members do not receive compensation but are allowed travel expenses. Federal Government employees may be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement. The Committee is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Congress recommends that community-based affiliates establish local advisory committees with employer representation. Funding for urban jobs programs is authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The funding amounts for fiscal years 2013 to 2016 are as follows: $30,000,000, $40,000,000, $50,000,000, and $60,000,000. A conforming amendment is made to the table of contents in the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. Sec. 173B. Urban jobs programs.
